Sections show prostatic tissue composed of glands of varying sizes and shapes, some of which are crowded and irregular. There is a focal area of atypical glands infiltrating the stroma. Mitotic figures are not readily identified. No invasion of the capsule or seminal vesicles is seen. The Gleason score is 4+3=7. Gleason pattern 4 is characterized by glands that are poorly formed, fused, or cribriform. Gleason pattern 3 is characterized by glands that are well-formed but crowded. The tumor involves approximately 10% of the core. The margins of the core are negative for tumor.

**Diagnosis:** Prostate, left lobe, core biopsy: Invasive adenocarcinoma of the prostate, Gleason score 4+3=7. Tumor involves approximately 10% of the core. Margins negative.

- High power view shows hepatocytes with varying degrees of steatosis (fatty change), ballooning degeneration, and Mallory-Denk bodies (hyaline inclusions).

- Bile duct proliferation and cholestasis (bile plugs) are also noted.
- Trichrome stain highlights the fibrous septa.

**Diagnosis:** Alcoholic liver disease with cirrhosis.

The DCIS is characterized by cribriform and solid patterns with nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and frequent mitotic figures. The invasive carcinoma demonstrates lymphovascular invasion (LVI). **Diagnosis:** Right Breast, Lumpectomy: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (IDC-NOS), High Grade (G3). Associated Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS), High Grade. Lymphovascular Invasion (LVI) present. Margins are negative for invasive carcinoma and DCIS.

Tumor cells are arranged in glandular structures and clusters, forming acini lined by a single layer of cuboidal to columnar cells with moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm and round nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Focal areas show papillary structures with fibrovascular cores. Other areas show lepidic growth along alveolar walls. Tumor cells are positive for TTF-1 and Napsin A. Immunohistochemistry for CK7 is positive, and CK20 is negative. The tumor cells are negative for p40 and p63, ruling out squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor invades the visceral pleura. The tumor margins are positive for carcinoma. Tumor grade is moderately differentiated (G2). Tumor size is 3.2 cm. Lymphovascular invasion is not identified. No lymph nodes are identified in the specimen.

**Diagnosis:** Left Upper Lobe, Lung, Wedge Resection: Invasive Adenocarcinoma, Moderately Differentiated (G2), 3.2 cm, with invasion of visceral pleura and positive margins.

**Final Diagnosis:** Invasive Adenocarcinoma, Moderately Differentiated (G2), Left Upper Lobe, Lung.

The tumor cells are positive for TTF-1 and Napsin A by immunohistochemistry. The tumor invades the visceral pleura. Pleural invasion is confirmed. The tumor does not involve the resection margins. The lymphovascular invasion is not identified.

**Diagnosis:** Adenocarcinoma, Moderately Differentiated, Left Lung.

**Additional Comments:** The tumor measures 1.8 cm in greatest dimension. The tumor invades the visceral pleura.

Representative sections are submitted for microscopic examination.

Invasion into the muscularis propria is not identified. The margins are negative for tumor. The resection is complete.

**Diagnosis:** Invasive Urothelial Carcinoma, High Grade.

**Additional Findings:** Cystitis.

**Comment:** The tumor is high grade and invasive, involving the lamina propria. The margins are negative, and the resection appears complete. Correlation with clinical findings is recommended.

**Clinical History:** 65-year-old male with a 3 cm lung mass found on CT scan. Patient is a former smoker (40 pack-years).

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show invasive carcinoma composed of nests and cords of atypical epithelial cells with moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm and round nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The tumor is immunohistochemically positive for CK7 and TTF-1, and negative for CK20 and p40.
**Diagnosis:** Invasive Adenocarcinoma, Right Lower Lobe Lung Biopsy.
**Final Comment:** The findings are consistent with invasive adenocarcinoma. The tumor shows features suggestive of higher grade malignancy based on mitotic activity and necrosis.

**Original Case Findings:**

**Clinical Information:** 69-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with a 5-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial lung disease. CT scan confirms bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial lung disease with honeycombing.

**Procedure:** Transbronchial lung biopsy, right middle lobe.

**Specimen Received:** One piece of lung tissue, 2 x 1 x 0.5 cm.

**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is one piece of lung tissue measuring 2 x 1 x 0.5 cm. The tissue is tan-brown and firm. It is entirely processed.

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show fragments of lung parenchyma with bronchioles and alveolar spaces. There is marked interstitial thickening due to fibrosis. Fibrosis is characterized by dense collagen deposition and myofibroblast proliferation. There is evidence of chronic inflammation with lymphocytes and plasma cells infiltrating the interstitium. Honeycombing is not seen in this small biopsy specimen. Honeycombing is typically seen in larger specimens or open lung biopsies. The airways show mild chronic bronchitis characterized by goblet cell hyperplasia and chronic inflammation. The vessels show mild intimal thickening. No granulomas are seen. No malignancy is seen.

**Diagnosis:** Interstitial lung disease, consistent with usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP). Chronic bronchitis.

**Comments:** The biopsy is small and may not be representative of the entire lung. Honeycombing, a key feature of UIP, was not seen in this biopsy, likely due to the small size of the specimen. However, the pattern of fibrosis and chronic inflammation is highly suggestive of UIP. Correlation with clinical and radiographic findings is recommended.

The polyethylene particles are identified within the foreign body reaction.

**Diagnosis:**

3.  Osteolysis secondary to wear debris.
4.  Wear of prosthetic components (femoral, tibial, patellar).

**Specimen:** Colon, sigmoid, resection

**Clinical History:** Patient with a history of ulcerative colitis for 20 years, presents with rectal bleeding and change in bowel habits. History of dysplasia found on previous surveillance colonoscopy.

**Gross Description:** Received is a segment of colon measuring 12 cm in length and 4.5 cm in diameter. The serosal surface is unremarkable. The mucosa is markedly abnormal, showing multiple ulcerations and nodularity. A lesion measuring 2.5 cm in diameter is identified in the sigmoid colon, appearing as a thickened, irregular mass with central ulceration. The lesion extends through the muscularis propria into the pericolonic fat. The resection margins are involved by dysplasia. Both margins are positive for dysplasia.

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show the sigmoid colon with severe dysplasia and invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated (Grade 2). The tumor is composed of irregular glands infiltrating the lamina propria and submucosa, extending through the muscularis propria into the pericolic adipose tissue. Tumor cells show moderate nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are readily identifiable. Lymphovascular invasion is present. Perineural invasion is not identified. No lymph node involvement is noted in the examined lymph nodes (0/12 nodes examined). The resection margins are positive for dysplasia.

**Diagnosis:** Invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated (Grade 2), sigmoid colon, arising in the setting of chronic ulcerative colitis with dysplasia.

**Original Case Findings Summary:**

*   **Micro:** Severe dysplasia and invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated (Grade 2). Infiltrates lamina propria, submucosa, muscularis propria, and pericolic fat. Lymphovascular invasion present. Perineural invasion absent. 0/12 lymph nodes positive. Margins positive for dysplasia.
*   **Diagnosis:** Invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated (Grade 2), sigmoid colon, arising in setting of chronic UC with dysplasia.

The invasive carcinoma demonstrates strong and diffuse nuclear staining for estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR). The carcinoma is negative for human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) by immunohistochemistry (IHC). The Ki-67 proliferation index is 15%. Lymphovascular invasion (LVI) is identified. Lymph nodes are not submitted.
**Diagnosis:** Right breast lumpectomy, invasive ductal carcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS), high grade (based on mitotic activity and pleomorphism). Adjacent high grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Margins are negative for invasive carcinoma and DCIS. ER positive (90%), PR positive (80%), HER2 negative (0/3+), Ki-67 15%. Lymphovascular invasion present.

**Microscopic Description:**
Sections show benign prostatic glands arranged in a papillary configuration. The glands are lined by a bilayered epithelium consisting of an inner tall columnar secretory epithelium and an outer basal cell layer. The stroma is fibromuscular and contains numerous inflammatory cells, predominantly lymphocytes and plasma cells.
There is evidence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN) involving approximately 20% of the glands. HGPIN is characterized by crowded, stratified nuclei with prominent nucleoli, loss of basal cell layer, and cribriforming.
There is also evidence of invasive adenocarcinoma, grade group 4 (Gleason score 4+3=7). The adenocarcinoma is characterized by irregular glands, fused glands, and poorly formed glands. The tumor cells have large, pleomorphic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The tumor involves approximately 30% of the TURP chips.
The margins are negative for invasive adenocarcinoma.

**Final Diagnosis:**
Prostate, transurethral resection:
- Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)
- High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN), involving 20% of glands
- Invasive adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+3=7, grade group 4, involving 30% of TURP chips, margins negative.

**Original Case Findings:**

**Specimen:** Left breast lumpectomy

**Clinical History:** 58-year-old female with a 2.5 cm palpable mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast.

**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is a modified radical mastectomy specimen consisting of the entire left breast, nipple-areolar complex, and axillary lymph nodes. The breast specimen measures 12 x 8 x 6 cm. The skin overlying the mass is unremarkable. The palpable mass measures 2.5 x 2.0 x 1.8 cm and is located in the upper outer quadrant, 3 cm from the superior border and 2 cm from the lateral border. The mass is firm, white-tan, and whorled. The nipple-areolar complex is intact. The axillary lymph nodes are identified and dissected. A total of 15 axillary lymph nodes are identified.

**Microscopic Description:**
*   **Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS):** The tumor is 2.5 cm in greatest dimension, located in the upper outer quadrant. It is composed of nests and cords of malignant epithelial cells infiltrating the stroma. The cells exhibit moderate nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and increased mitotic activity. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is present adjacent to the invasive carcinoma.
*   **Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS):** High grade, extensive DCIS is present, involving the majority of the breast tissue. The DCIS is characterized by cribriform and solid patterns with central necrosis.
*   **Axillary Lymph Nodes:** 15 axillary lymph nodes are examined. 3 out of 15 lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma. Metastatic carcinoma is characterized by nests of malignant epithelial cells infiltrating the lymph node parenchyma.

**Final Diagnosis:** Left breast modified radical mastectomy. Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), 2.5 cm, upper outer quadrant, with extensive high-grade DCIS. Metastatic carcinoma involving 3 out of 15 axillary lymph nodes.

**Specimen Type:** Punch biopsy of skin lesion

**Clinical History:** A 65-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of a growing, non-healing ulcer on his left forearm. The lesion is described as erythematous, indurated, and tender.

**Gross Description:** Received is a single, 4 x 3 x 2 mm, elliptical, tan-white tissue core. The entire specimen is submitted in one cassette.

**Microscopic Description:** Histologic sections show a moderately cellular infiltrate of atypical lymphocytes within the dermis. These lymphocytes are predominantly small to medium-sized, with irregular nuclear contours, clumped chromatin, and inconspicuous nucleoli. Mitotic figures are infrequent. There is associated epidermotropism, with lymphocytes infiltrating the epidermis, forming Pautrier's microabscesses. The overlying epidermis shows mild acanthosis and parakeratosis. The dermis shows some degree of fibrosis.

**Diagnosis:** Cutaneous T-cell Lymphoma (CTCL), Mycosis Fungoides type.

**Ancillary Studies:** Immunohistochemistry (IHC) was performed. The atypical lymphocytes are positive for CD3, CD4, and CD5. They are negative for CD8, CD20, and CD30.

**Comment:** The histologic features, particularly the epidermotropism with Pautrier's microabscesses and the immunophenotype (CD3+, CD4+, CD5+, CD8-, CD20-, CD30-), are characteristic of Mycosis Fungoides, a subtype of Cutaneous T-cell Lymphoma (CTCL).

**Original Case Findings:**

**Specimen:** Left upper lobe, lung, wedge resection.
**Clinical History:** 68-year-old male with a 2 cm solitary pulmonary nodule found incidentally on CT scan.
**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is a 2.5 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm portion of lung tissue, consistent with a wedge resection. The specimen weighs 18 grams. The surface is unremarkable. The cut surface reveals a firm, white-tan, spherical nodule measuring 1.8 x 1.5 x 1.3 cm, located centrally within the specimen. The nodule is well-circumscribed. The surrounding lung parenchyma is unremarkable. Representative sections are submitted.
**Microscopic Description:** Sections show a well-circumscribed, encapsulated neoplasm composed of uniform cells with round nuclei, clear cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli. The cells are arranged in nests and cords, separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. Mitotic figures are rare. Necrosis and hemorrhage are absent. The tumor cells stain positive for TTF-1 and Napsin A. The tumor cells are negative for p40 and p63. The Ki-67 proliferation index is approximately 5%. The tumor is located within the lung parenchyma, adjacent to the pleura. The pleural surface is free of tumor. The lymphovascular invasion is not identified. No residual normal lung parenchyma is seen.
**Diagnosis:** Lung, left upper lobe, wedge resection: Adenocarcinoma, lepidic predominant, measuring 1.8 cm in greatest dimension. Margins are negative for tumor.
**Comment:** The tumor is well-differentiated (Grade 1) based on the low mitotic rate and absence of necrosis. The immunohistochemical profile (TTF-1+, Napsin A+, p40-, p63-) is consistent with primary lung adenocarcinoma. The low Ki-67 proliferation index (5%) also supports a low-grade tumor. The tumor is lepidic predominant, which is a subtype of adenocarcinoma in situ or minimally invasive adenocarcinoma.

---

**Original Case Findings:**

**Specimen:** Right Breast Core Biopsy
**Clinical History:** 38-year-old female with a palpable mass in the right breast.
**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is a single core biopsy specimen, measuring 1.2 x 0.3 cm and 1.1 x 0.2 cm in diameter, respectively. The core is tan-white and intact.
**Microscopic Description:** Sections show invasive ductal carcinoma, not otherwise specified (IDC-NOS), comprising approximately 80% of the tumor volume. The tumor cells are arranged in nests and cords, exhibiting moderate pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are readily identifiable, averaging 15 per 10 high-power fields (HPF). Necrosis is present. The tumor is associated with extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), high grade, involving the majority of the remaining ductal structures. The DCIS component exhibits cribriform and solid architectural patterns. The surrounding stroma shows a moderate desmoplastic reaction. Lymphovascular invasion (LVI) is not identified. Margins are clear.
**Immunohistochemistry:**
*   Estrogen Receptor (ER): Positive (80% of tumor cells, strong intensity)
*   Progesterone Receptor (PR): Positive (60% of tumor cells, moderate intensity)
*   HER2: Negative (0/3+ by IHC)
*   Ki-67: 25%
**Diagnosis:** Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (IDC-NOS), Grade 3. Extensive associated Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS), High Grade.
**Margins:** Clear.
**Lymphovascular Invasion:** Not identified.
**Comment:** The tumor is ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER2-negative. The Ki-67 proliferation index is 25%.

**Diagnosis:**
Chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis.

**Clinical History:** 54-year-old female with a history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and prior radiation therapy to the chest. Patient presents with a new mass in the left upper lobe (LUL) of the lung.

The immunohistochemical stains show that the atypical lymphoid cells are positive for CD20, CD5, CD10, and BCL6. The atypical lymphoid cells are negative for CD3, CD30, and PAX5. The Ki-67 proliferation index is approximately 60%. The findings are consistent with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), not otherwise specified (NOS).

**Diagnosis:** Left upper lobe (LUL) lung mass, core biopsy: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), not otherwise specified (NOS).

**Final Diagnosis:** Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), not otherwise specified (NOS).

**Original Case Findings:**

**Clinical History:** 50-year-old female with a history of alcohol abuse. Presents with jaundice, weight loss, and abdominal pain.

**Gross Description:** Liver biopsy specimen shows a nodular, shrunken liver with a firm, yellowish-tan cut surface. There are multiple small, pale yellow nodules scattered throughout the parenchyma, consistent with regenerative nodules. Cirrhosis is noted.

**Microscopic Description:**
- Low power view shows diffuse fibrosis separating hepatocytes into nodules.
- High power view shows hepatocytes with varying degrees of steatosis (fatty change), ballooning degeneration, and Mallory-Denk bodies (hyaline inclusions).
- Inflammatory infiltrate composed mainly of neutrophils and lymphocytes is present in the portal tracts and sinusoids.
- Bile duct proliferation and cholestasis (bile plugs) are also noted.
- Trichrome stain highlights the fibrous septa.

**Diagnosis:** Alcoholic liver disease with cirrhosis.

Multiple small, pale yellow nodules, suggestive of regenerative nodules, are dispersed throughout the hepatic parenchyma. The overall appearance is consistent with cirrhosis.

**Microscopic Description:**
- Low power examination reveals diffuse fibrosis that partitions the hepatocytes into nodules.
- High power examination demonstrates hepatocytes displaying varying degrees of steatosis, ballooning degeneration, and the presence of Mallory-Denk bodies.
- An inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of neutrophils and lymphocytes, is observed within the portal tracts and sinusoids.
- Bile duct proliferation and cholestasis are evident.
- Trichrome stain confirms the presence of fibrous septa.

**Diagnosis:** Alcoholic liver disease with cirrhosis.

**Original Case Findings:**

**Specimen:** Right ureter, partial nephrectomy specimen

**Clinical History:** Patient with history of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) involving the right kidney and ureter.

**Gross Description:** Received is a partial nephrectomy specimen consisting of the upper pole of the right kidney and the proximal ureter. The kidney portion measures 10 x 8 x 6 cm. The renal parenchyma shows a well-circumscribed, tan-yellow, solid mass measuring 7 x 6 x 5 cm, located in the upper pole. The mass is moderately firm. The ureter measures 15 cm in length and is unremarkable. The remaining renal parenchyma is grossly normal. The specimen is entirely received.

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show a neoplasm composed of cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli, arranged in nests and cords. The tumor cells exhibit moderate nuclear pleomorphism and frequent mitotic figures. Features consistent with clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) are present. The tumor invades the perirenal fat. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion (LVI). Margins are negative for tumor. The ureter is unremarkable. The remaining renal parenchyma is normal.

**Diagnosis:** Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC), upper pole of right kidney, invading perirenal fat.

**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is a wedge-shaped lung specimen measuring 6.0 x 4.5 x 3.0 cm. The specimen weighs 55 grams. The pleural surface is unremarkable. The cut surface reveals a firm, white-tan, spiculated mass measuring 2.2 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm, located centrally within the lung parenchyma. The mass is contiguous with the visceral pleura. The remainder of the lung parenchyma is unremarkable. All tissue is submitted in cassette A1.

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show a malignant neoplasm composed of atypical squamous cells arranged in nests and sheets, with intercellular bridges and keratinization. Individual cell features include large, pleomorphic nuclei with prominent nucleoli and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are readily identified. Necrosis is present within the tumor. The tumor invades the visceral pleura. There is no lymphovascular invasion identified. No metastatic carcinoma is identified in the lung parenchyma.

**Diagnosis:** Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Left Upper Lobe Wedge Resection.

**Margins:** Visceral pleura margin is involved by tumor.

**Comment:** The tumor is consistent with squamous cell carcinoma. The visceral pleura margin is involved.

---

Immunohistochemistry for CK7 is positive, and CK20 is negative. The tumor cells are negative for p40 and p63, ruling out squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor invades the visceral pleura. The tumor margins are positive for carcinoma. Tumor grade is moderately differentiated (G2). Tumor size is 3.2 cm. Lymphovascular invasion is not identified. No lymph nodes are identified in the specimen.

**Diagnosis:** Left Upper Lobe, Lung, Wedge Resection: Invasive Adenocarcinoma, Moderately Differentiated (G2), 3.2 cm, with invasion of visceral pleura and positive margins.

**Final Diagnosis:** Invasive Adenocarcinoma, Moderately Differentiated (G2), Left Upper Lobe, Lung.

**Original Case Findings:**

**Clinical History:** 55-year-old male with a 6-month history of right-sided flank pain and hematuria.

**Imaging:** CT scan reveals a 4.5 cm complex cystic and solid mass in the upper pole of the right kidney.

**Specimen Received:** Right nephrectomy specimen.

**Gross Description:** Received is a right kidney measuring 12 x 8 x 6 cm. The kidney weighs 450 grams. The upper pole contains a 4.5 cm, partially exophytic, tan-white, solid and cystic mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. The mass is located adjacent to the renal hilum. The remainder of the kidney parenchyma is unremarkable.

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show a renal mass composed of large polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli. The cells are arranged in nests and cords. Mitotic figures are numerous (estimated 15 per 10 high-power fields). Necrosis and hemorrhage are present. The tumor invades the perinephric fat. There is no lymphovascular invasion identified.

**Diagnosis:** Renal Cell Carcinoma, Clear Cell Type.

**Grade:** ISUP Grade 4 (High Grade).

**Margins:** Perinephric fat margin is involved by tumor.

**Microscopic Findings:** Sections show a renal mass composed of large polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli. The cells are arranged in nests and cords. Mitotic figures are numerous (approximately 15/10 HPF). Necrosis and hemorrhage are present. The tumor invades the perinephric fat. No lymphovascular invasion was identified.

**Diagnosis:** Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma.

**Grade:** ISUP Grade 4.

**Margins:** The perinephric fat margin is involved by tumor.

The generated report accurately reflects the original case

**Original Case Findings:**

**Specimen Type:** Colon, sigmoid, partial colectomy
**Clinical History:** Diverticulitis, rule out malignancy
**Gross Description:** Received is a partial colectomy specimen consisting of a segment of sigmoid colon measuring 15 cm in length and 8.5 cm in diameter. The serosal surface is unremarkable. The specimen is opened to reveal a thickened colonic wall measuring up to 1.5 cm in thickness. Within the lumen, there is a 2.5 cm mass lesion identified. The mass is firm, tan-white, and slightly nodular. The mass is located approximately 8 cm from the distal margin. The distal margin is free of tumor. The proximal margin is free of tumor. The pericolic fat is unremarkable. The lymph nodes are unremarkable.
**Microscopic Description:** Sections show a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, tubular type. The tumor cells are arranged in irregular glands with moderate nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are readily identifiable. The tumor invades the submucosa. The tumor does not invade the muscularis propria. The tumor does not invade the serosa. The lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma.
**Diagnosis:** Adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, tubular type, sigmoid colon. Tumor invades submucosa (pT1). Lymph nodes negative (pN0).

---

Honeycombing is not seen in this small biopsy specimen. Honeycombing is typically seen in larger specimens or open lung biopsies. The airways show mild chronic bronchitis characterized by goblet cell hyperplasia and chronic inflammation. The vessels show mild intimal thickening. No granulomas are seen. No malignancy is seen.

**Diagnosis:** Interstitial lung disease, consistent with usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP). Chronic bronchitis.

**Comments:** The biopsy is small and may not be representative of the entire lung. Honeycombing, a key feature of UIP, was not seen in this biopsy, likely due to the small size of the specimen. However, the pattern of fibrosis and chronic inflammation is highly suggestive of UIP. Correlation with clinical and radiographic findings is recommended.

**Final Diagnosis:**

The closest margin is the anterior margin. The mass is 4 cm from the posterior margin, 3 cm from the medial margin, and 3.5 cm from the lateral margin. The surrounding breast tissue is unremarkable.
2. Left axillary lymph node dissection: Received in formalin is a specimen containing 16 lymph nodes. The lymph nodes range in size from 0.2 cm to 2.5 cm in greatest dimension.

**Microscopic Description:**
1. Left mastectomy: Sections show invasive ductal carcinoma, not otherwise specified (IDC-NOS). The tumor is composed of nests and cords of malignant epithelial cells with pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are frequent. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is present, involving the ducts adjacent to the invasive carcinoma. The tumor invades lymphovascular structures. Lymphovascular invasion (LVI) is identified. The tumor size is 4.5 cm.
2. Left axillary lymph node dissection: Sections show metastatic carcinoma in 3 of 16 lymph nodes. The metastatic carcinoma is consistent with the primary invasive ductal carcinoma. The largest focus of metastatic carcinoma measures 1.5 cm.

**Final Diagnosis:**
Left breast, simple mastectomy: Invasive ductal carcinoma, not otherwise specified (IDC-NOS), 4.5 cm in greatest dimension, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Lymphovascular invasion (LVI) is present. Margins are negative.
Left axillary lymph node dissection: Metastatic carcinoma (consistent with primary) in 3 of 16 lymph nodes. Largest focus 1.5 cm.

**Diagnosis:** Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Left Lung.

**Additional Comments:** All surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma. Lymphovascular invasion is not identified.

The femoral component shows significant wear on the articular surface. The tibial component shows moderate wear. The patellar component shows minimal wear. The polyethylene insert of the tibial component is fragmented and worn. The surrounding soft tissues include synovium, ligaments, and bone fragments. The synovium is thickened and inflamed. The ligaments are intact. The bone fragments are consistent with osteolysis.

There is evidence of osteolysis surrounding the prosthetic components, characterized by multinucleated giant cells and bone resorption. The polyethylene particles are identified within the foreign body reaction.

**Diagnosis:**

2.  Foreign body reaction to prosthetic components.
3.  Osteolysis secondary to wear debris.
4.  Wear of prosthetic components (femoral, tibial, patellar).

**Original Case Findings:**

**Specimen:** Colon, sigmoid, resection

**Clinical History:** Patient with a history of ulcerative colitis for 20 years, presents with rectal bleeding and change in bowel habits. History of dysplasia found on previous surveillance colonoscopy.

**Gross Description:** Received is a segment of colon measuring 12 cm in length and 4.5 cm in diameter. The serosal surface is unremarkable. The mucosa is markedly abnormal, showing multiple ulcerations and nodularity. A lesion measuring 2.5 cm in diameter is identified in the sigmoid colon, appearing as a thickened, irregular mass with central ulceration. The lesion extends through the muscularis propria into the pericolonic fat. The resection margins are involved by dysplasia. Both margins are positive for dysplasia.

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show the sigmoid colon with severe dysplasia and invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated (Grade 2). The tumor is composed of irregular glands infiltrating the lamina propria and submucosa, extending through the muscularis propria into the pericolic adipose tissue. Tumor cells show moderate nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are readily identifiable. Lymphovascular invasion is present. Perineural invasion is not identified. No lymph node involvement is noted in the examined lymph nodes (0/12 nodes examined). The resection margins are positive for dysplasia.

**Diagnosis:** Invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated (Grade 2), sigmoid colon, arising in the setting of chronic ulcerative colitis with dysplasia.

**Original Case Findings Summary:**

*   **Diagnosis:** Invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated (Grade 2), sigmoid colon, arising in setting of chronic UC with dysplasia.

**Original Case Findings:**

**Patient:** 72M
**Specimen:** Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)
**Clinical History:** BPH, elevated PSA

**Gross Description:**
Multiple fragments of prostatic tissue, ranging in size from 0.1 to 1.5 cm in aggregate. The largest fragment measures 1.5 x 1.0 x 0.8 cm. The tissue is tan-white and firm. No definite tumor is identified grossly.

**Microscopic Description:**
Sections show benign prostatic glands arranged in a papillary configuration. The glands are lined by a bilayered epithelium consisting of an inner tall columnar secretory epithelium and an outer basal cell layer. The stroma is fibromuscular and contains numerous inflammatory cells, predominantly lymphocytes and plasma cells.
There is evidence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN) involving approximately 20% of the glands. HGPIN is characterized by crowded, stratified nuclei with prominent nucleoli, loss of basal cell layer, and cribriforming.
There is also evidence of invasive adenocarcinoma, grade group 4 (Gleason score 4+3=7). The adenocarcinoma is characterized by irregular glands, fused glands, and poorly formed glands. The tumor cells have large, pleomorphic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The tumor involves approximately 30% of the TURP chips.
The margins are negative for invasive adenocarcinoma.

**Final Diagnosis:**
Prostate, transurethral resection:
- Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)
- High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN), involving 20% of glands
- Invasive adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+3=7, grade group 4, involving 30% of TURP chips, margins negative.

**Original Case Findings:**

**Specimen:** Left breast lumpectomy

**Clinical History:** 58-year-old female with a 2.5 cm palpable mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast.

**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is a modified radical mastectomy specimen consisting of the entire left breast, nipple-areolar complex, and axillary lymph nodes. The breast specimen measures 12 x 8 x 6 cm. The skin overlying the mass is unremarkable. The palpable mass measures 2.5 x 2.0 x 1.8 cm and is located in the upper outer quadrant, 3 cm from the superior border and 2 cm from the lateral border. The mass is firm, white-tan, and whorled. The nipple-areolar complex is intact. The axillary lymph nodes are identified and dissected. A total of 15 axillary lymph nodes are identified.

**Microscopic Description:**
*   **Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS):** The tumor is 2.5 cm in greatest dimension, located in the upper outer quadrant. It is composed of nests and cords of malignant epithelial cells infiltrating the stroma. The cells exhibit moderate nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and increased mitotic activity. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is present adjacent to the invasive carcinoma.
*   **Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS):** High grade, extensive DCIS is present, involving the majority of the breast tissue. The DCIS is characterized by cribriform and solid patterns with central necrosis.
*   **Axillary Lymph Nodes:** 15 axillary lymph nodes are examined. 3 out of 15 lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma. Metastatic carcinoma is characterized by nests of malignant epithelial cells infiltrating the lymph node parenchyma.

**Final Diagnosis:** Left breast modified radical mastectomy. Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), 2.5 cm, upper outer quadrant, with extensive high-grade DCIS. Metastatic carcinoma involving 3 out of 15 axillary lymph nodes.

**Specimen Type:** Punch biopsy of skin lesion

**Clinical History:** A 65-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of a growing, non-healing ulcer on his left forearm. The lesion is described as erythematous, indurated, and tender.

**Gross Description:** Received is a single, 4 x 3 x 2 mm, elliptical, tan-white tissue core. The entire specimen is submitted in one cassette.

**Microscopic Description:** Histologic sections show a moderately cellular infiltrate of atypical lymphocytes within the dermis. These lymphocytes are predominantly small to medium-sized, with irregular nuclear contours, clumped chromatin, and inconspicuous nucleoli. Mitotic figures are infrequent. There is associated epidermotropism, with lymphocytes infiltrating the epidermis, forming Pautrier's microabscesses. The overlying epidermis shows mild acanthosis and parakeratosis. The dermis shows some degree of fibrosis.

**Diagnosis:** Cutaneous T-cell Lymphoma (CTCL), Mycosis Fungoides type.

**Ancillary Studies:** Immunohistochemistry (IHC) was performed. The atypical lymphocytes are positive for CD3, CD4, and CD5. They are negative for CD8, CD20, and CD30.

**Comment:** The histologic features, particularly the epidermotropism with Pautrier's microabscesses and the immunophenotype (CD3+, CD4+, CD5+, CD8-, CD20-, CD30-), are characteristic of Mycosis Fungoides, a subtype of Cutaneous T-cell Lymphoma (CTCL).

**Specimen:** Left upper lobe, lung, wedge resection.
**Clinical History:** 68-year-old male with a 2 cm solitary pulmonary nodule found incidentally on CT scan.
**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is a 2.5 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm portion of lung tissue, consistent with a wedge resection. The specimen weighs 18 grams. The surface is unremarkable. The cut surface reveals a firm, white-tan, spherical nodule measuring 1.8 x 1.5 x 1.3 cm, located centrally within the specimen. The nodule is well-circumscribed. The surrounding lung parenchyma is unremarkable. Representative sections are submitted.
**Microscopic Description:** Sections show a well-circumscribed, encapsulated neoplasm composed of uniform cells with round nuclei, clear cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli. The cells are arranged in nests and cords, separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. Mitotic figures are rare. Necrosis and hemorrhage are absent. The tumor cells stain positive for TTF-1 and Napsin A. The tumor cells are negative for p40 and p63. The Ki-67 proliferation index is approximately 5%. The tumor is located within the lung parenchyma, adjacent to the pleura. The pleural surface is free of tumor. The lymphovascular invasion is not identified. No residual normal lung parenchyma is seen.
**Diagnosis:** Lung, left upper lobe, wedge resection: Adenocarcinoma, lepidic predominant, measuring 1.8 cm in greatest dimension. Margins are negative for tumor.
**Comment:** The tumor is well-differentiated (Grade 1) based on the low mitotic rate and absence of necrosis. The immunohistochemical profile (TTF-1+, Napsin A+, p40-, p63-) is consistent with primary lung adenocarcinoma. The low Ki-67 proliferation index (5%) also supports a low-grade tumor. The tumor is lepidic predominant, which is a subtype of adenocarcinoma in situ or minimally invasive adenocarcinoma.

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show invasive ductal carcinoma, not otherwise specified (IDC-NOS), comprising approximately 80% of the tumor volume. The tumor cells are arranged in nests and cords, exhibiting moderate pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are readily identifiable, averaging 15 per 10 high-power fields (HPF). Necrosis is present. The tumor is associated with extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), high grade, involving the majority of the remaining ductal structures. Margins are clear.

*   Estrogen Receptor (ER): Positive (80% of tumor cells, strong intensity)
*   Progesterone Receptor (PR): Positive (60% of tumor cells, moderate intensity)
*   HER2: Negative (0/3+ by IHC)
*   Ki-67: 25%
**Diagnosis:** Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (IDC-NOS), Grade 3. Extensive associated Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS), High Grade.
**Margins:** Clear.
**Lymphovascular Invasion:** Not identified.
**Comment:** The tumor is ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER2-negative. The Ki-67 proliferation index is 25%.

These glands are crowded, irregular in shape, and lack the usual basal cell layer. The nuclei are enlarged, hyperchromatic, and show prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are occasionally seen. The atypical glands are associated with focal stromal invasion. There is no evidence of high-grade features such as cribriform pattern, poorly formed glands, or fused glands. There is no lymphovascular invasion.
**Diagnosis:** Prostate, left lobe, core 1, biopsy: Adenocarcinoma, Gleason Score 3+4=7. Gleason pattern 3 accounts for approximately 90% of the tumor, and Gleason pattern 4 accounts for approximately 10% of the tumor.

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show invasive ductal carcinoma, not otherwise specified (IDC-NOS), comprising approximately 80% of the tumor volume. The tumor cells are arranged in nests and cords, exhibiting moderate nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and frequent mitotic figures. Nuclear grade is 2 (moderately differentiated). The tumor shows extensive comedonecrosis. Comedonecrosis is defined as central necrosis with dystrophic calcification. The tumor cells are positive for estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR), and negative for HER2/neu (IHC 1+). The Ki-67 proliferation index is 15%. The tumor invades lymphovascular structures. Lymphovascular invasion (LVI) is defined as the presence of tumor cells within lymphatic or blood vessels. The margins of the core biopsy are involved by tumor.

**Diagnosis:** Right Breast Core Needle Biopsy: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (IDC-NOS), Nuclear Grade 2.

**Additional Findings:**
- Comedonecrosis: Present
- ER: Positive
- PR: Positive
- HER2/neu: Negative (IHC 1+)
- Ki-67: 15%
- Lymphovascular Invasion: Present
- Margins: Involved

**Original Case Findings:**

**Clinical History:** 54-year-old female with a history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and prior radiation therapy to the chest. Patient presents with a new mass in the left upper lobe (LUL) of the lung.

**Imaging:** CT scan of the chest shows a 2.5 cm spiculated mass in the LUL with mediastinal lymphadenopathy.

**Specimen:** Left upper lobe (LUL) lung mass, core biopsy.

**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is a core biopsy specimen measuring 1.5 cm in length and 0.3 cm in diameter. The core contains multiple fragments of lung parenchyma with a central nodule.

**Microscopic Description:** The core biopsy shows fragments of lung parenchyma with a central nodule composed of atypical lymphoid cells. The atypical lymphoid cells are medium-sized with irregular nuclear contours, coarse chromatin, and prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are present. The background stroma shows fibrosis and inflammation. The atypical lymphoid cells infiltrate the surrounding lung parenchyma. The immunohistochemical stains show that the atypical lymphoid cells are positive for CD20, CD5, CD10, and BCL6. The atypical lymphoid cells are negative for CD3, CD30, and PAX5. The Ki-67 proliferation index is approximately 60%. The findings are consistent with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), not otherwise specified (NOS).

**Diagnosis:** Left upper lobe (LUL) lung mass, core biopsy: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), not otherwise specified (NOS).

**Final Diagnosis:** Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), not otherwise specified (NOS).

**Original Case Findings:**

**Patient:** 73-year-old male
**Specimen:** Prostate, left lobe, core biopsy
**Clinical History:** Elevated PSA (12.4 ng/mL)
**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is a single core of prostatic tissue, measuring 1.5 cm in length and 0.1 cm in diameter. The core is entirely submitted.
**Microscopic Description:** Sections show prostatic tissue with benign glands and stroma. Scattered throughout the core are nests of atypical glands. These glands are irregular in shape, crowded, and show nuclear enlargement, pleomorphism, and loss of polarity. Mitotic figures are occasionally seen. The atypical glands are infiltrating the surrounding benign prostatic tissue. There is no evidence of high-grade features such as ductal adenocarcinoma or neuroendocrine differentiation. There is no ink-capsule involvement. No seminal vesicle invasion.
**Diagnosis:** Prostate, left lobe, core biopsy: Adenocarcinoma, Gleason Score 3+4=7. Gleason pattern 3: Scattered glands with atypical features. Gleason pattern 4: Irregular, crowded glands with nuclear enlargement and pleomorphism.

**Clinical History:** 65-year-old male with a 3 cm lung nodule found on CT scan. Patient is a former smoker (40 pack-years).

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show fragments of lung parenchyma with prominent anthracotic pigmentation. There are scattered clusters of atypical squamous cells with large, pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. These cells exhibit features of squamous differentiation, including intercellular bridges and keratinization. **Comment:** The biopsy is diagnostic of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Correlation with clinical and radiological findings is recommended.

**Original Case Findings:**

**Patient:** 76-year-old female
**Specimen:** Right lower lobe lung biopsy
**Clinical History:** 6-month history of cough, recent weight loss.
**Gross Description:** Received in formalin, labeled "Right lower lobe lung biopsy". The specimen consists of multiple, irregular fragments of tan-white tissue, ranging in size from 0.1 to 0.5 cm. The largest fragment measures 0.5 x 0.3 x 0.2 cm. All fragments are submitted in cassette A1.
**Microscopic Description:** Sections show fragments of lung parenchyma containing metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells are arranged in glandular patterns, forming acini and tubules. The cells exhibit moderate nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. Mitotic figures are infrequent. Necrosis is present. The tumor cells are positive for TTF-1 and Napsin A, consistent with lung primary adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells are negative for p40 and CK5/6, ruling out squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor cells are also negative for CD20 and CD45, ruling out lymphoma. The tumor cells are negative for chromogranin and synaptophysin, ruling out neuroendocrine carcinoma. The tumor cells are negative for PAX8 and GATA3, ruling out thyroid or breast primary. The tumor cells are negative for calretinin, ruling out mesothelioma. The tumor cells are negative for Melan-A, ruling out melanoma. The tumor cells are negative for CD117, ruling out GIST.
**Diagnosis:** Metastatic adenocarcinoma, likely primary lung.
**Comments:** The immunohistochemical profile (TTF-1+, Napsin A+, p40-, CK5/6-, CD20-, CD45-, chromogranin-, synaptophysin-, PAX8-, GATA3-, calretinin-, Melan-A-, CD117-) is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma of lung primary origin.

**Original Case Findings:**

**Specimen:** Left axillary lymph node, core biopsy

**Clinical History:** Positive sentinel lymph node biopsy from right axilla. Patient has invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast.

**Gross Description:** Received in formalin is a core biopsy of lymph node tissue, measuring 1.7 x 0.3 x 0.3 cm. The core contains tan-brown tissue.

**Microscopic Description:** Sections show lymph node tissue with preserved architecture. There is focal effacement of the nodal architecture by metastatic carcinoma. The metastatic carcinoma consists of nests and cords of malignant epithelial cells with large, pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are readily apparent. The metastatic carcinoma cells are positive for CK7 and GATA3, and negative for CK20 and TTF1. The lymph node contains reactive sinus histiocytosis.

**Diagnosis:** Left axillary lymph node, core biopsy: Metastatic carcinoma, consistent with metastatic invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast.

**Immunohistochemistry:**
CK7: Positive
GATA3: Positive
CK20: Negative
TTF1: Negative

**Comment:** The findings are consistent with metastatic carcinoma from the breast.
